children: A 33-year-old woman is evaluated for the sudden appearance of a rapidly expanding painful skin lesion on her leg. She had a miscarriage 1 year ago. Her activated partial thromboplastin time is prolonged.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APAS), an autoimmune disorder in which thrombosis and fetal demise (in pregnancy) may occur. This patient's large area of jaggedly branching, angulated retiform purpura is a manifestation of intravascular clot formation in the small vessels of the skin, leading to overlying skin necrosis. Angulated retiform purpura can be the presenting manifestation of APAS.

Diagnosis of APAS is based on the clinical criteria of thromboembolism or pregnancy morbidity and laboratory findings of medium- or high-titer antiphospholipid antibodies (anticardiolipin antibodies and lupus anticoagulant) present on two or more occasions at least 12 weeks apart. A clue to the presence of lupus anticoagulant is prolongation of activated partial thromboplastin time, as seen with this patient.
